description: On August 27, Ethiopia re-opened all government and private schools for the start of the coming school year. description: On April 26, Ethiopia's Somali regional state announced a curfew on vehicular movement from 8.00 p.m. to 6.00 a.m. throughout all small towns and cities of the state. People are still around to move on foot but punishment for driving during the curfew are up to three years of jail or a fine of between 1,000 and 3,000 US dollars.

compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Ethiopia's northern Tigray regional state on Thursday, March 26, announced a region-wide state of emergency as a means of combating the coronavirus pandemic for 15 days.

Ethiopia's northern Tigray regional state on Thursday, March 26, announced a region-wide state of emergency as a means of combating the coronavirus pandemic for 15 days, extended to a duration of 3 months. UPDATE: Extension of the state of emergency to an overall duration of 3 months alongside relaxation of other measures.

Ethiopia imposes a five-month State of Emergency to curb the spread of COVID-19, suspending constitutional rights under Article 93 of the constitution, granting the Council of Ministers 'all necessary power to protect the country's peace and sovereignty', from April 8 for 5 months. Failure to comply with the measures could lead to up to three years of imprisonment or a fine between 1,000 and 200,000 Ethiopian Birr, enforced by the security forces where necessary.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: From April 10, Ethiopia's House of Peoples' Representatives enacted a 5-months State of Emergency in an effort to limit the spread of the Coronavirus (COVID-19). The State was initially declared by the Government on April 8 according to Article 93 of the Constitution.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

On March 16, Ethiopia asked private bus companies to join in providing free public transport. UPDATE: On March 16, Ethiopia asked private transporters to join the government in offering free public transport.

Ethiopia expands correction facilities and utilises other holding spaces to avoid overcrowding, while new prisoners will be tested, visits will be suspended and prisoners with minor offences and near released date will be released from imprisonment as of March 20.
type_text: Isolation and avoidance of overcrowding within prison facilities to avoid containment.

description: Ethiopia is announcing actions to be taken against individuals and businesses that are exploiting the health situation and profiting from the above market sell of consumer goods, from March 20. UPDATE: The PM announces actions to be taking against individuals and businesses exploiting the health situation.
type_text: The policy aims to prevent exploitation by acting against individuals and businesses that elevate prices, hence introducing price controls.

description: Ethiopia raises awareness of public health with preventive sanitation and hygiene measures on March 13, 2020.
On March 16, Ethiopia is asking volunteers to support in raising prevention awareness.

On March 20, Ethiopia released a policy paper stating the of harassment of foreign nationals as "not acceptable and un-Ethiopian", emphasizing the need to undertake prevention measures instead.

Ethiopia demands the media to play a focused and critical role in raising prevention awareness at all levels, from March 23. UPDATE: The government demands the media to take a focused and critical role in raising awareness.

Ethiopia in encouraging religious institutions and places of worship to stop gatherings and undertake worship through other means in order to limit and halt the spread of COVID-19 from March 20. Ethiopia in encouraging religious institutions and places of worship to stop gatherings and undertake worship through other means in order to limit and halt the spread of COVID-19 from March 20.
